citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Medications and vaccines were not stored at the correct temperature per the label. Three types of vaccine labels’ stated
to store between 35-46 degrees Fahrenheit and the temperature in the refrigerator was 32 degrees Fahrenheit. Two
bottles of Bactracillin G (Penicillin injectable) label states to store between 36-46 degrees Fahrenheit were stored in the
same refrigerator.
An un-labeled syringe and needle with clear liquid inside was on the countertop on a whelping barn. The licensee states
this is a syringe of oxytocin and was not aware of storage requirements or expiration date of the medication. All
medications must be properly labeled and stored appropriately according to the label.
Medications not stored at correct temperature or are improperly labeled do not ensure that the medications are effective
at treating or preventing diseases or illness and the health of the animal may suffer. Each dealer shall use appropriate
methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. The licensee must ensure all medications are
stored at the correct temperature per the label and are labeled appropriately.

The facility uses microchips placed under the dog's skin as their form of official identification for dogs over 16 weeks of
age. There were at least 10 dogs (9 Huskies and 1 Dachshund) over the age of 16 weeks without a readable microchip
with a scanner. An acceptable form of official identification (listed below) is necessary for APHIS officials to positively
identify animals for inspection and to properly trace their movements.
All live dogs over the age of 16 weeks shall be identified by an official tag affixed to a collar around the animal’s neck, by
a legible tattoo marking approved by the Administrator, or by a microchip placed under the dog’s skin. The licensee must
apply one of these forms of identification to the dog. The licensee must ensure that all dogs have an official form of
identification at all times.

The licensee uses cage cards as the form of identification for puppies under 4 months of age. At least two litters of
puppies have been assigned unique official identification numbers but several litters still have the same numbering since
the last inspection. Each litter has a cage card and lists out each puppy 01 and up. When sold, the licensee adds a breed
abbreviation before that number. There is no distinct number given between puppies of the same breeds. Identification of
each puppy is necessary for APHIS officials to identify each puppy and trace their movements. The licensee must identify
each puppy under 16 weeks of age by an official tag, a distinctive and legible tattoo approved by the Administrator or a
plastic-type collar acceptable to the Administrator which has legibly placed thereon the required information or a cage
card with all required information including a unique identification number.
To be corrected by: 16-January-2024

Required information was missing in the acquisition and disposition records for dogs at this facility.
-The facility uses cage cards as the record of acquisition for the dogs born at the facility. The cage cards were missing the
unique official identification number and breed of the puppies, the dam's official identification number and the description
of each puppy.
-The Record of Acquisition of Dogs and Cats on Hand (APHIS form 7005) is missing acquisition information for several
adult dogs including the address and USDA number of the person the dog was acquired from. The acquisition date was
also missing for several adult dogs.
-On a 27-December-2023 Record of Disposition of Dogs and Cats on Hand (APHIS form 7006), it has inaccurate dates of
birth for three Bichon-poo puppies. The form states DOB of 2-November-2023 but the actual DOB is 9-November-2023.
-At least one Record of Disposition of Dogs and Cats on Hand (APHIS form 7006) are missing the official identification of
each dog and the address and USDA number for the buyer for two adult dogs sent to a licensed facility for breeding.
-The licensee is not recording the address and registration numbers for transportation companies on the Record of
Disposition of Dogs and Cats on Hand (APHIS form 7006)
-On one Record of Disposition of Dogs and Cats on Hand (APHIS form 7006) ten microchipped puppies only had the last
four digits of the microchip number listed. The full microchip number is required to be recorded as it is the dog’s official
identification.
Accurate acquisition information is necessary for APHIS officials to make positive identification of animals during
inspection and to properly trace their movements. The licensee shall make, keep, and maintain an approved method of
documentation which fully and correctly disclose all information concerning each dog purchased or otherwise acquired,
owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or
otherwise disposed of by that dealer. The records shall include any offspring born of any animal while in his or her
possession or under his or her control. The licensee must record all required acquisition and disposition information and
have it accurately documented at all times.

Three 48-day old male red bichon-poo puppies born on 9-November-2023 were transported in commerce with a group of
puppies that the buyer picked up on 27-December-2023. Puppies transported or sold in commerce before 8 weeks of age
may cause additional stress and increase risk of health problems. Ensure puppies sold or transported in commerce are at
least 8 weeks of age (56 days) and have been weaned.
To be corrected by: 10-January-2024

This facility does not have enough employees to maintain the minimum level of care required by the Animal Welfare Act.
Currently the licensee is the full-time caregiver to the 111 adult dogs and 42 puppies with occasional help from their
spouse. This includes but is not limited to cleaning, feeding, sanitizing, observing, providing veterinary care and keeping
accurate and up to date records. The high number of citations (10) found in the last inspection report and on this current
report suggest that the current number of employees is inadequate to provide the level of husbandry practices and care
required in this subpart. Facilities without adequate staffing may cause animals to suffer from lack of care. The licensee
must have adequate staffing to carry out the level of husbandry practices and care required in this subpart.
To be corrected by: 2-February-2024.

The licensee is missing medical records detailing when problems are identified and details regarding how those
conditions are treated.
-French Bulldog MC#933000320591069 was examined by a licensed veterinarian on 22-December-2023 and prescribed
Firocoxib 57mg for 7 days and to place on a diet. There is no record of this treatment being given and no dietary changes
are recorded. The licensee states the medication was given and the inspector observed that the lameness has improved.
The licensee states this dog is not free fed anymore and is given a limited amount of the normal dog food.
-French Bulldog MC#900233001207976, a phone call was made to a licensed veterinarian on treatment for swelling
between the toes on right front foot. The veterinarian stated to monitor for improvement. The swellings on the right front
foot are healing but at the time of inspection, swellings have started on the left front foot. The licensee states she will be
taking this dog to the veterinarian tomorrow for treatment. No records of veterinarian treatment recommended by phone,
or the identification of the new swellings were available at the time of inspection.
Without proper documentation, it is difficult to determine the efficacy of a treatment plan and ensure the animals are
receiving adequate veterinary care. A proper medical record includes the identification of the animal, date the problem
was found, a description of the problem, the name and frequency and amount of medications used, examination findings,
test results, plans for treatment and care, and treatment procedures performed must be recorded and a copy kept for
review for inspection by APHIS officials. Correct by ensuring all records of any treatments for problems identified in the
dogs are recorded and maintained at all times.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Medications and vaccines were not stored at the correct temperature per the label. Three types of vaccine labels’ stated

medications must be properly labeled and stored appropriately according to the label.

at treating or preventing diseases or illness and the health of the animal may suffer. Each dealer shall use appropriate 
methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. The licensee must ensure all medications are 
stored at the correct temperature per the label and are labeled appropriately.

Time and method of identification.

2.75(a)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
Required information was missing in the acquisition and disposition records for dogs at this facility. 
-The facility uses cage cards as the record of acquisition for the dogs born at the facility. The cage cards were missing the

-The Record of Acquisition of Dogs and Cats on Hand (APHIS form 7005) is missing acquisition information for several

-At least one Record of Disposition of Dogs and Cats on Hand (APHIS form 7006) are missing the official identification of 
each dog and the address and USDA number for the buyer for two adult dogs sent to a licensed facility for breeding. 
-The licensee is not recording the address and registration numbers for transportation companies on the Record of 
Disposition of Dogs and Cats on Hand (APHIS form 7006) 
-On one Record of Disposition of Dogs and Cats on Hand (APHIS form 7006) ten microchipped puppies only had the last

identification. 
Accurate acquisition information is necessary for APHIS officials to make positive identification of animals during

2.130 
   
Minimum age requirements. 
Three 48-day old male red bichon-poo puppies born on 9-November-2023 were transported in commerce with a group of 
puppies that the buyer picked up on 27-December-2023. Puppies transported or sold in commerce before 8 weeks of age 
may cause additional stress and increase risk of health problems. Ensure puppies sold or transported in commerce are at 
least 8 weeks of age (56 days) and have been weaned. 
To be corrected by: 10-January-2024

3.12 
   
Employees 
This facility does not have enough employees to maintain the minimum level of care required by the Animal Welfare Act. 
Currently the licensee is the full-time caregiver to the 111 adult dogs and 42 puppies with occasional help from their 
spouse. This includes but is not limited to cleaning, feeding, sanitizing, observing, providing veterinary care and keeping

must have adequate staffing to carry out the level of husbandry practices and care required in this subpart. 
To be corrected by: 2-February-2024. 
3.13(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee is missing medical records detailing when problems are identified and details regarding how those 
conditions are treated. 
-French Bulldog MC#933000320591069 was examined by a licensed veterinarian on 22-December-2023 and prescribed
